q: That's exactly what the state's congressional delegation asked for last week in a letter to Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius . Her agency has until March 31 to decide whether to grant an extension. The waiver should absolutely be extended, Kirsten Gillibrand said. "These are exactly the kind of solutions we need right now. as encouraging investment. The bitter campaign split Italy's powerful labor unions. Sergio Marchionne praised the "courage" of workers who gave their approval. Saying yes to flexibility makes it possible to achieve very high production levels, of up to 280,000 vehicles per year, and also open the way for the potential creation of jobs, Sergio Marchionne said in a statement. "In a country such as Italy, which has always been tied to the past and reluctant to change... those who voted yes showed vision," he said.

Windows tablets- a "slew of them"- will be unveiled by Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer at the 2011 Consumer Electronics Show, according to an article today in the New York Times. Citing people familiar with Microsoft's plans, the Times reports that several manufacturers have signed up to build Windows tablets, including Dell and Samsung. by the prospect of Mike Pence running for governor. "I think he's the clear front-runner, and I think the race is his if he chooses to accept it," Jackie Walorski said. I think he'd clear the field. Gov. Mitch Daniels , who is considering a run for president himself, has reached his two-term limit and can not run again in 2012. Mike Pence was one of three heavyweight candidates considering the race.

shared the stage with Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer whose company-like Stephen Elop 's- has been looking to gain traction in the heated smartphone space currently dominated by Apple's iPhone lineup and smartphones running Google's Android OS. Mr. Stephen Elop has probably made his biggest decision of his career, and for all intents and purposes it appears to be the right one, IDC analyst Al Hilwa said in a Feb. 11 report. 's not hosting Super party DALLAS-- NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell is not concerned about Michael Vick being billed as hosting a Super Bowl party because the Eagles quarterback told him it's not true. He has said that on numerous occasions people have been using his name about being involved in some type of a party and he had no intention of participating in that, Roger Goodell said.
